title: ‘One-man crimewave’ led to murder of shopkeeper for £100 in till
text:
Career criminal Alex Gunn stabbed Ravi Katharkamar to death for his till takings (Picture: PA/Central News)

A ‘one-man crimewave’ who stabbed a hardworking shopkeeper to death for his £100 till takings is facing a life sentence.

Alex Gunn, 31, was captured on CCTV knifing 54-year-old Ravi Katharkamar at Marsh Food and Wine in Pinner, northwest London, shortly after opening time on March 24.

Following his conviction at the Old Bailey Mr Katharkamar’s widow Vignarani Aiyathirai described the ‘devastation’ of losing the ‘kind, humorous and loving’ family man.

In a statement read to the court she said: ‘A stranger fatally and brutally stabbed Ravi for the £100 or so float from the till. The thought of this haunts me.

‘I cannot bear the thought of Ravi being in pain and then dying there, where he was attacked, on the floor of the shop.

Gunn was described in court as a ‘one-man crimewave’ (Picture: PA)

Mr Katharkamar was described as a ‘kind, humorous and loving’ family man (Picture: PA)

‘I hate the fact he was alone, that I was not there to hold or comfort him, tend to his wounds or tell him I loved him and that all would be OK.

‘No, he died alone with no-one around him.

‘I constantly wonder if the man who did this will ever realise or care that he has left such a huge trail of devastation within my family.’

Ms Aiyathirai said her husband had been ‘defenceless against a violent man who thought nothing of using a knife’.

Jurors were told CCTV footage showed Gunn holding a knife to Mr Katharkamar’s throat and grappling with him before plunging the blade into his chest.

Gunn left him there, grabbing the till and fleeing in a stolen black Vauxhall Astra.

A jogger found the shopkeeper collapsed in the doorway and called the emergency services who pronounced him dead at the scene shortly after arriving.

He had suffered two knife wounds, one of which fractured a rib and punctured his lung and heart.

Gunn crept up on Mr Katharkamar from behind as he set out the Sunday newspapers (Picture: Central News)

He stabbed the shopkeeper in the heart and fled in a stolen Vauxhall Astra (Picture: Central News)

Despite covering up in a balaclava and gloves, his build and movements gave Gunn away (Picture: PA)

The court heard Gunn paid two earlier visits to the store, including one the previous week timed almost to the minute.

When he was arrested in the Astra five days after the fatal robbery he had changed the number plates in an effort to avoid detection.

Prosecutor William Emlyn Jones said Gunn was ‘sufficiently savvy’ to have covered himself up with a balaclava and gloves during the raid.

But jurors heard his build and movements along with security footage proved to be his undoing.

Mr Emlyn Jones described the killer as a ‘one-man crimewave’ who had also carried out a series of burglaries and thefts to fund his drug habit.

Gunn, from Pinner, was convicted of murder, robbery, four burglaries, three thefts and two counts of possession of a bladed article and will be sentenced on Friday.

Detective Chief Inspector Simon Stancombe, of Scotland Yard, said: ‘Ravi Katharkamar and Alex Gunn couldn’t be more different.

‘Ravi was a warm and loving father and husband. A man who worked long hours to support his young family and run his shop in the heart of the local community in Pinner.

‘Alex Gunn, on the other hand, is a career criminal who has spent much of his adult life preying on other people.

‘Alex Gunn is an odious, vile and dangerous individual who I am pleased to say will now be in prison for a very long time.’
